triples.name: Political polarization
triples.relevance: The paper directly studies political polarization as the central phenomenon of investigation across social media platforms.

triples.name: Social media
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes political discussions on social media platforms as the primary data source and field of study.

triples.name: Twitter
triples.relevance: Twitter is one of three social media platforms analyzed to examine patterns of political polarization.

triples.name: Facebook
triples.relevance: Facebook is one of three social media platforms analyzed to examine patterns of political polarization and inter-group interaction.

triples.name: WhatsApp
triples.relevance: WhatsApp is one of three social media platforms analyzed, showing unique de-polarization patterns over time.

triples.name: Homophily
triples.relevance: Homophily (preference for interaction with similar others) is a key concept used to analyze interactional polarization patterns.

triples.name: Communication studies
triples.relevance: The paper employs computational communication science approaches to analyze political conversations and interactions.

triples.name: Political discourse
triples.relevance: Political discourse on social media is the subject being analyzed across platforms and over time.

triples.name: Interactional polarization
triples.relevance: The paper introduces interactional polarization as a novel measurement framework capturing homophilic versus heterophilic user interactions.

triples.name: Positional polarization
triples.relevance: The paper proposes positional polarization as a novel framework to measure the positions expressed by users in political discourse.

triples.name: Affective polarization
triples.relevance: The paper introduces affective polarization as a novel measurement framework capturing emotions and attitudes expressed in political discourse.
